segments.text: Stack Overflow is dead. When Stack
Overflow first started in 2008, 4,000
questions were asked in its first few
months. Now, in 2026, it is the exact
same amount. 17 years of growth
completely erased. And yes, of course,
it's because of AI, but I also think
Stack Overflow had its own problems, and
this graph tells that story. So, let's
talk about this and why this is scary
for the future of the web. I mean, man,
the new web is really starting to suck.
Let's go through this graph in stages as
it really does tell the journey of Stack
Overflow. Stack Overflow starts in 2008
and until 2014, you can see its growth
is great. It peaks at around 200,000 new
questions a month. And I mean, it was
great, right? There was finally a place
for crowdsource problem solving and
people actually liked helping others and
the points gamified it and made people
feel like experts. Software felt
friendly and no one can deny how useful
Stack Overflow was. I mean, there was
always jokes that developers literally
stopped working if Stack Overflow was
down. I bet you wouldn't even notice if
it went down today. To me, it was second
to Wikipedia for crowdsource knowledge.
Another great place for developer
knowledge is this channel. So, subscribe
because apparently 80% of you aren't and
we are so close to 100,000. 2014 is also
where the rapid growth stops and Chachi
PT is still 8 years away from release.
So, what happened? Well, if you've used
Stack Overflow after 2014, you probably
already know the answer to this. It was
the moderation. 2014 is when Stack
Overflow implemented better moderation
tools, more efficient question closing,
and faster removal of lowquality
content. And in theory, all of this made
sense with how big Stack Overflow was
getting. It's definitely not an easy
task to moderate a platform like that.
You want to maintain a high signal to
noise ratio to keep the answers actually
useful. But just a single Google search
for Stack Overflow moderators, and
you'll see what the opinion of this
change was. I remember personally being
fearful of asking dumb questions on
there when I started my coding journey
as I always saw threads were closed for
duplicate off-topic unclear what you're
asking did you even try searching and I
mean at the time I was around 13 when I
first started coding and my school's IT
lesson was can you open Microsoft Word
I'm not even joking I had to do a test
on that so I basically had nowhere else
to go to ask these dumb questions I get
I was probably just an annoying kid but
I think the point system could have
solved this on its own to me it just
started to feel like you had to be in
the inner circle of Stack Overflow users
to actually use the platform. But I also
do see an argument for why they need
this moderation. The co-founders were
terrified of becoming Yahoo Answers. The
co-founder Jeff Atwood actually admitted
to this saying, "We're strict about this
because we've seen what happens when
systems are not explicit about their
goals. This way lies madness. This way
lies Yahoo Answers." So you can almost
think of the point of Stack Overflow is
not to help the person asking the
question, but to prioritize helping
those who would later reach the question
via Google. It was supposed to be high
friction and therefore it was supposed
to have a high standard for the
questions and the answers. And yes, I
think it did work a little bit. Every
time I Googled a problem, Stack Overflow
was usually the top and I usually got an
answer. Stack Overflow was pretty high
quality. But also, how many times did
you reach a Stack Overflow post, see it
was closed for duplication, go to the
original, and it was either not the fix
that you needed or it was just
completely outdated. This was that
problem. Software moves really fast. If
we look for webdev questions, a lot of
them are going to be related to Internet
Explorer or jQuery. And that doesn't
matter when I'm asking a question in
2020. And their opinion was that you
just go back and update the answer on
the original question. But I think
that's just a bad user experience all
around. This comment on Hacker News
summarizes it really well. Every now and
then I'd get a new notification about
someone telling me I was completely
wrong and should be embarrassed. Look,
my time traveling friend, that answer
was perfectly reasonable when I wrote it
16 years ago. I'm not going to go back
and fix all my old suggestions to keep
them up to date. People just want to
find the latest question and answer, so
just let a new one exist. And don't
expect people to go back to that old
thread to keep it updated. The
moderation problem got bad enough that
Stack Overflow did acknowledge it
themselves in a blog post in 2018
titled, "Stack overflow isn't very
welcoming. It's time for this to
change." Even they admitted that too
many people experienced Stack Overflow
as either a hostile or elitist place,
especially new coders. It just feels
like Stack Overflow could have done a
little bit better if the moderation was
a little softer. And I think this graph
shows that the questions just start to
slowly decline only having a peak in
2020 when everyone was in lockdown and I
assume they couldn't easily ask a
colleague. But another interesting thing
about this period is after the lockdown
the questions start to decline faster
than before and again chatbas hasn't
come out yet. Now I don't really know
the explanation for this faster decline.
The only thing I can think of is the
dark horse in this discussion which is
Discord, Slack, and Reddit. Now, Reddit
is an okay place for software answers,
but I still don't find it that good. The
worst experience over there is finding
the exact issue that you're having,
seeing a comment with the answer
deleted, and a comment under that saying
solved. It is incredibly annoying. But
then we also have Discord and Slack
where each community and tool seems to
be creating their own space for their
own experts to answer questions. And I
really like these developer communities.
They are really friendly and I find
they're way nicer to beginners and
beginners tend to get pushed in the
right place in a much nicer tone. The
only issue with them is that we've lost
the ease of finding an answer and the
knowledge is just now siloed. Discord
doesn't appear on Google and I can't be
expected to be in every single developer
Discord and know the right one to find a
solution to my problem. There is
actually a super cool tool aiming to fix
this called answer overflow made by Ree
and it just aims to make these Discord
threads searchable. And I would love it
if every single Discord starts to use
this and if Google starts to rank these
answers highly, but I don't think we're
there yet. Now going back to our graph,
we are very close in this journey to the
point where chat GBT is released. But
something kind of funny that isn't shown
on this graph is that the original
founders of Stack Overflow sold it to
private equity for 1.8 billion in June
2021 before LLM came out. That is some
incredible timing. So props to them on
that. But now we have reached AI's
impact, November 30, 2022. This is the
day that chat GBT was released. And
every issue that I just mentioned about
Stack Overflow is the advantage of chat
GBT. Most importantly, we had instant
answers and no judgment. You can ask the
most basic question and it won't call
you an idiot. It will just give you the
answers. I really wish I had this when I
first started out coding. Although, I do
wonder how much I would have actually
been learning other than just copy and
pasting the answer that chat GBT gives
me. Regardless, you can see on the chart
that AI is the final nail in the coffin.
Questions declined rapidly and we're now
here back at the beginning. This is just
quite a sad story to me because it's not
one of a company simply becoming
outdated and being replaced with a
better, newer competitor. This is just
way worse. Problem is, chat and LLM
wouldn't be what they are today without
Stack Overflow. All of those years of
human expertise, carefully cured
answers, upvoted solutions, debates in
the comments, the collective brains of
millions of developers essentially just
got stolen for free. And it's ironic
that Stack Overflow built the training
data that created its own replacement.
And I also see this as just another
story in the trend of taking public
information that the internet made as a
community and causing it to be gatekept
or paywalled in the future. We've
already seen big examples of this. The
Reddit API became stupidly expensive to
try and stop LLM scraping, leading to
apps like Apollo shutting down, which I
absolutely loved. And the same thing
goes for the Twitter API. These sites
just realized they have so much data
that it benefits them not to let it be
extracted by someone else and instead be
used by them. We've even seen signs of
this on Stack Overflow. They used to
provide data dumps of the site so if the
company ever turned evil, the community
could rebuild. But even that quietly
stopped and it's probably so they could
pay all that knowledge and as expected
they partnered with OpenAI to provide
API access and were even working on an
overflow AI. Although oddly I can't seem
to find out what's happened to this one
as the page here just goes to a 404. So
there we go. This is the internet in
2026 and beyond and it's getting scary.
AI is starting to change the entire way
that we've used the web in the last 20
years, and I'm not so sure it's for the
better. There are some positives of this
story, I suppose, which is communities
like Discord are awesome places to hang
out, but there's a whole lot of
negatives in here. And that's not even
mentioning what AI is doing to art,
music, and videos. I really want to know
what you think in the comments. Did you
have a positive experience on Stack
Overflow? And do you have any optimism
for the future of the web? Let me know.
And while you're down there, subscribe.
And as always, see you in the next one.

Now, in 2026, it is the exact same amount. 17 years of growth completely erased. And yes, of course, it's because of AI, but I also think Stack Overflow had its own problems, and this graph tells that story. So, let's talk about this and why this is scary for the future of the web. I mean, man, the new web is really starting to suck. Let's go through this graph in stages as it really does tell the journey of Stack Overflow. Stack Overflow starts in 2008 and until 2014, you can see its growth is great. Well, if you've used Stack Overflow after 2014, you probably already know the answer to this. It was the moderation. 2014 is when Stack Overflow implemented better moderation tools, more efficient question closing, and faster removal of lowquality content. And in theory, all of this made sense with how big Stack Overflow was getting. It's definitely not an easy task to moderate a platform like that. But just a single Google search for Stack Overflow moderators, and you'll see what the opinion of this change was. I remember personally being fearful of asking dumb questions on there when I started my coding journey as I always saw threads were closed for duplicate off-topic unclear what you're asking did you even try searching and I mean at the time I was around 13 when I first started coding and my school's IT lesson was can you open Microsoft Word I'm not even joking I had to do a test on that so I basically had nowhere else to go to ask these dumb questions I get I was probably just an annoying kid but I think the point system could have solved this on its own to me it just started to feel like you had to be in the inner circle of Stack Overflow users to actually use the platform. But I also do see an argument for why they need this moderation. The co-founders were terrified of becoming Yahoo Answers. The co-founder Jeff Atwood actually admitted to this saying, "We're strict about this because we've seen what happens when systems are not explicit about their goals. This way lies madness. This way lies Yahoo Answers." So you can almost think of the point of Stack Overflow is not to help the person asking the question, but to prioritize helping those who would later reach the question via Google. It was supposed to be high friction and therefore it was supposed to have a high standard for the questions and the answers. And yes, I think it did work a little bit. But also, how many times did you reach a Stack Overflow post, see it was closed for duplication, go to the original, and it was either not the fix that you needed or it was just completely outdated. People just want to find the latest question and answer, so just let a new one exist. And don't expect people to go back to that old thread to keep it updated. The moderation problem got bad enough that Stack Overflow did acknowledge it themselves in a blog post in 2018 titled, "Stack overflow isn't very welcoming. It's time for this to change." Even they admitted that too many people experienced Stack Overflow as either a hostile or elitist place, especially new coders. It just feels like Stack Overflow could have done a little bit better if the moderation was a little softer. And I think this graph shows that the questions just start to slowly decline only having a peak in 2020 when everyone was in lockdown and I assume they couldn't easily ask a colleague. And every issue that I just mentioned about Stack Overflow is the advantage of chat GBT. Most importantly, we had instant answers and no judgment. You can ask the most basic question and it won't call you an idiot. It will just give you the answers. I really wish I had this when I first started out coding. Although, I do wonder how much I would have actually been learning other than just copy and pasting the answer that chat GBT gives me. Regardless, you can see on the chart that AI is the final nail in the coffin. Questions declined rapidly and we're now here back at the beginning. This is just quite a sad story to me because it's not one of a company simply becoming outdated and being replaced with a better, newer competitor. This is just way worse. Problem is, chat and LLM wouldn't be what they are today without Stack Overflow. And it's ironic that Stack Overflow built the training data that created its own replacement. And I also see this as just another story in the trend of taking public information that the internet made as a community and causing it to be gatekept or paywalled in the future. We've already seen big examples of this. The Reddit API became stupidly expensive to try and stop LLM scraping, leading to apps like Apollo shutting down, which I absolutely loved. And the same thing goes for the Twitter API. These sites just realized they have so much data that it benefits them not to let it be extracted by someone else and instead be used by them. We've even seen signs of this on Stack Overflow. They used to provide data dumps of the site so if the company ever turned evil, the community could rebuild. But even that quietly stopped and it's probably so they could pay all that knowledge and as expected they partnered with OpenAI to provide API access and were even working on an overflow AI. Although oddly I can't seem to find out what's happened to this one as the page here just goes to a 404. So there we go. This is the internet in 2026 and beyond and it's getting scary. AI is starting to change the entire way that we've used the web in the last 20 years, and I'm not so sure it's for the better. There are some positives of this story, I suppose, which is communities like Discord are awesome places to hang out, but there's a whole lot of negatives in here. And that's not even mentioning what AI is doing to art, music, and videos. I really want to know what you think in the comments. Did you have a positive experience on Stack Overflow? And do you have any optimism for the future of the web? Let me know. And while you're down there, subscribe. And as always, see you in the next one.
